titleStmt.title: In view of that progress
a hand-written transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This scrap is a draft of Whitman's essay "Five Thousand Poems," first published in The Critic, number 172, April 16, 1887. It was later reprinted in Democratic Vistas and Other Papers (London, 1888), and November Boughs (1888). The language on this leaf appears nearly verbatim in "Five Thousand Poems." On the verso is a partial letter to Whitman from the office of The Critic.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: [In view of that progress]
bibl.orgName: The Thomas Biggs Harned Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
On the verso is a partial letter to Whitman from the office of The Critic.

body.p:
In view of the past,that progress, and of evolution. The
religious element important of any, is‸seems to me more indebted to poetry than to all other means and influences combined. In a very profound sense, religion is the poetry of humanity, and neither could exist without the other...The.

Then, after all is said, and the seemingly unfathomable gaps and contradicts pointed out, the points of union and rapport among all the distinctive poems, ‸and last, of the world—however wide thetheir separations of time and place ‸and curiously so much more rous and weighty than of contrast.
